q1.text: What is the maximum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) allowed for drivers in the Netherlands?
q1.explanation: The maximum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) allowed for drivers in the Netherlands is 0.05%. This is lower than many other countries to improve road safety.

q2.text: What is the maximum BAC for drivers with less than 5 years of experience?
q2.explanation: Drivers with less than 5 years of experience have a stricter BAC limit of 0.02%, which is essentially zero tolerance.

q3.text: What is the penalty for driving with a BAC between 0.05% and 0.08%?
q3.explanation: Driving with a BAC between 0.05% and 0.08% results in a fine of €240 and possible license suspension.

q4.text: What is the penalty for driving with a BAC above 0.08%?
q4.explanation: Driving with a BAC above 0.08% is a criminal offense that can result in imprisonment, heavy fines, and mandatory license suspension.

q5.text: How long should you wait after drinking alcohol before driving?
q5.explanation: The safest approach is to wait at least 24 hours after drinking alcohol before driving. Your judgment of when you feel sober is not reliable.

q6.text: What drugs are illegal to drive under the influence of in the Netherlands?
q6.explanation: It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug that affects your driving ability, including cannabis, prescription medications, and over-the-counter drugs.
q6.o1: Only hard drugs like cocaine and heroin
q6.o3: All drugs that affect driving ability

q7.text: What should you do if you are taking medication that may affect your driving?
q7.explanation: If you are taking medication that may affect your driving, you should check with your doctor or pharmacist about whether it is safe to drive.
q7.o3: Check with your doctor or pharmacist

q8.text: What are the signs of drug-impaired driving?
q8.explanation: Signs of drug-impaired driving include erratic driving behavior, slow reaction times, poor judgment, and difficulty maintaining lane position.
q8.o3: Erratic driving, slow reactions, and poor judgment

q9.text: What is the penalty for refusing a breathalyzer test?
q9.explanation: Refusing a breathalyzer test carries the same penalty as driving under the influence, as it is considered an admission of guilt.
q9.o3: Same penalty as driving under the influence

q10.text: How long does alcohol stay in your system?
q10.explanation: Alcohol can stay in your system for 24-48 hours, depending on factors like body weight, metabolism, and amount consumed.

q11.text: What should you do if you suspect another driver is under the influence?
q11.explanation: If you suspect another driver is under the influence, call the police emergency number (112) and provide the vehicle description and location.

q12.text: What is the best way to prevent drunk driving?
q12.explanation: The best ways to prevent drunk driving are to designate a sober driver, take a taxi or public transport, or stay overnight. Never drive after drinking.
q12.o2: Take a taxi or public transport

q1.text: You approach an intersection with a bicycle crossing. A cyclist is waiting to cross. What should you do?
q1.explanation: At bicycle crossings, motorists must stop and give way to cyclists who are waiting to cross or already crossing.
q1.o1: Stop and give way to the cyclist

q2.text: You want to turn right at an intersection. A cyclist is approaching from the opposite direction, also turning right. Who has priority?
q2.explanation: Cyclists have priority when turning right at intersections. Motorists must give way to cyclists in this situation.
q2.o2: You have priority as a motorist

q3.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane. What is the minimum distance you must maintain when overtaking?
q3.explanation: When overtaking cyclists, you must maintain a minimum distance of 1.5 meters to ensure their safety.

q4.text: You are driving in a 30 km/h zone. A cyclist is riding ahead of you at 20 km/h. What should you do?
q4.explanation: In 30 km/h zones, you should follow cyclists at a safe distance rather than overtaking, as the speed difference is minimal.
q4.o2: Follow behind at a safe distance
q4.o3: Honk to make the cyclist move faster

q5.text: You are parking your car. You see a bicycle lane next to the parking space. What should you do?
q5.explanation: Always check for approaching cyclists before opening your car door when parking next to a bicycle lane to prevent accidents.
q5.o1: Park normally, cyclists can go around
q5.o2: Check for cyclists before opening your door
q5.o3: Park closer to the bicycle lane to save space

q6.text: You are driving on a road without a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding on the right side of the road. What should you do?
q6.explanation: When there is no bicycle lane, cyclists have the right to use the road. Maintain a safe distance and overtake only when it is safe to do so.
q6.o1: Drive as close as possible to the cyclist
q6.o2: Maintain a safe distance and overtake when possible
q6.o3: Honk to make the cyclist move to the side

q7.text: You are approaching a roundabout. A cyclist is already in the roundabout. What should you do?
q7.explanation: At roundabouts, you must give way to traffic already in the roundabout, including cyclists.
q7.o1: Enter the roundabout, cyclists must give way
q7.o2: Wait for the cyclist to exit the roundabout
q7.o3: Enter and overtake the cyclist immediately

q8.text: You are driving on a narrow road. A cyclist is approaching from the opposite direction. What should you do?
q8.explanation: On narrow roads, slow down and give cyclists extra space when passing to ensure their safety.
q8.o1: Continue driving, the cyclist must move aside
q8.o2: Slow down and give the cyclist extra space
q8.o3: Stop completely and let the cyclist pass

q9.text: You are driving at night. You see a cyclist ahead without proper lighting. What should you do?
q9.explanation: When encountering a cyclist without proper lighting at night, slow down and pass with extra caution to ensure safety.
q9.o1: Flash your headlights to warn the cyclist
q9.o2: Slow down and pass with extra caution

q10.text: You are driving in a residential area. Children are riding bicycles on the street. What should you do?
q10.explanation: In residential areas with children cycling, reduce your speed and be extra vigilant as children may not always follow traffic rules.
q10.o1: Drive normally, children should be careful
q10.o2: Reduce speed and be extra vigilant

q11.text: You are driving on a road with a shared bicycle and pedestrian path. A cyclist is using the path. What should you do?
q11.explanation: When driving near shared bicycle and pedestrian paths, be aware that cyclists may need to enter the road and be prepared to give way.
q11.o1: Ignore the cyclist, they are on a separate path
q11.o2: Be aware that the cyclist may enter the road
q11.o3: Honk to warn the cyclist to stay on the path

q12.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. The bicycle lane is blocked by roadworks. What should you do?
q12.explanation: When a bicycle lane is blocked, cyclists may need to use the main road. Be extra careful and give them space.
q12.o2: Be extra careful as cyclists may use the main road
q12.o3: Honk to warn cyclists about the roadworks

q13.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding outside the bicycle lane. What should you do?
q13.explanation: Cyclists are not always required to use bicycle lanes. Respect their choice and maintain a safe distance when passing.
q13.o1: Honk to make the cyclist use the bicycle lane
q13.o3: Drive as close as possible to force them into the lane

q14.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane but swerving slightly. What should you do?
q14.explanation: When a cyclist is swerving, they may be avoiding obstacles or have difficulty maintaining balance. Give extra space and pass with caution.
q14.o2: Give extra space and pass with caution
q14.o3: Drive as close as possible to keep them in line

q15.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane but appears to be looking at their phone. What should you do?
q15.explanation: When a cyclist appears distracted, give extra space and pass with caution. Honking may startle them and cause an accident.
q15.o2: Give extra space and pass with caution
q15.o3: Drive as close as possible to get their attention

q16.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane but appears to be intoxicated. What should you do?
q16.explanation: When a cyclist appears intoxicated, give extra space and pass with extreme caution. Their behavior may be unpredictable.
q16.o2: Give extra space and pass with extreme caution
q16.o3: Drive as close as possible to keep them in line

q17.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane but appears to be having mechanical problems. What should you do?
q17.explanation: When a cyclist appears to have mechanical problems, give extra space and pass with caution as they may need to stop suddenly.
q17.o2: Give extra space and pass with caution
q17.o3: Drive as close as possible to keep them moving

q18.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane but appears to be lost or confused. What should you do?
q18.explanation: When a cyclist appears lost or confused, give extra space and pass with caution as they may make unexpected movements.
q18.o2: Give extra space and pass with caution
q18.o3: Drive as close as possible to guide them

q19.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane but appears to be in distress. What should you do?
q19.explanation: When a cyclist appears to be in distress, stop and offer help if it is safe to do so. Otherwise, give extra space and pass with caution.
q19.o2: Give extra space and pass with caution
q19.o3: Stop and offer help if safe to do so

q20.text: You are driving on a road with a bicycle lane. A cyclist is riding in the bicycle lane but appears to be racing. What should you do?
q20.explanation: When a cyclist appears to be racing, give extra space and pass with caution as their behavior may be unpredictable.
q20.o2: Give extra space and pass with caution
q20.o3: Drive as close as possible to keep them in line

q1.text: You are driving and see a construction zone ahead. What should you do?
q1.explanation: In construction zones, you must reduce your speed and be extra careful due to potential hazards and workers.
q1.o1: Reduce speed and be extra careful
q1.o3: Speed up to get through quickly

q2.text: You are driving in a construction zone and see workers on the road. What should you do?
q2.explanation: When workers are present in construction zones, give them extra space and drive slowly to ensure their safety.
q2.o1: Give extra space to workers and drive slowly

q3.text: You are driving in a construction zone and see a temporary speed limit sign. What should you do?
q3.explanation: Temporary speed limit signs in construction zones must be followed. They are legally enforceable and designed for safety.
q3.o2: Continue driving at the normal speed limit

q4.text: You are driving in a construction zone and see a lane closure. What should you do?
q4.explanation: When a lane is closed in a construction zone, merge into the open lane when it is safe to do so.
q4.o1: Merge into the open lane when safe
q4.o2: Continue driving in the closed lane
q4.o3: Stop and wait for the lane to reopen

q5.text: You are driving in a construction zone and see a flag person directing traffic. What should you do?
q5.explanation: Flag persons in construction zones have authority to direct traffic. You must follow their directions for safety.
q5.o3: Honk to get the flag person\

q6.text: You are driving in a construction zone and see construction equipment on the road. What should you do?
q6.explanation: When construction equipment is on the road, give it extra space and drive slowly to avoid accidents.
q6.o1: Give extra space to the equipment and drive slowly
q6.o3: Speed up to get past the equipment quickly

q7.text: You are driving in a construction zone and see a detour sign. What should you do?
q7.explanation: Detour signs in construction zones indicate alternative routes. You must follow the detour route for safety.
q7.o2: Continue driving on the original route

q8.text: You are driving in a construction zone and see a "Road Work Ahead" sign. What should you do?
q8.explanation: When you see a "Road Work Ahead" sign, prepare to slow down and be extra careful as you approach the construction zone.
q8.o1: Prepare to slow down and be extra careful
q8.o3: Speed up to get through quickly

q1.text: What should you do if you are involved in a traffic accident?
q1.explanation: If you are involved in a traffic accident, you must stop immediately and check for injuries. Call emergency services if needed.
q1.o2: Stop immediately and check for injuries
q1.o3: Wait for someone else to call the police

q2.text: What is the emergency number in the Netherlands?
q2.explanation: The emergency number in the Netherlands is 112. This number connects you to police, fire, and ambulance services.

q3.text: When should you call the emergency number 112?
q3.explanation: Call 112 for life-threatening situations and serious accidents where immediate assistance is needed.
q3.o3: For life-threatening situations and serious accidents

q4.text: What should you do if you witness a traffic accident?
q4.explanation: If you witness a traffic accident, stop and offer assistance if it is safe to do so. Call emergency services if needed.
q4.o2: Stop and offer assistance if safe to do so

q5.text: What should you do if your vehicle breaks down on a motorway?
q5.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a motorway, get out and stand behind the safety barrier. Use emergency phones to call for assistance.
q5.o2: Get out and stand behind the barrier
q5.o3: Walk along the motorway to find help

q6.text: What should you do if you see an emergency vehicle with lights and sirens?
q6.explanation: If you see an emergency vehicle with lights and sirens, move to the right and slow down to allow it to pass safely.
q6.o2: Move to the right and slow down
q6.o3: Speed up to get out of the way

q7.text: What should you do if you are involved in a minor accident with no injuries?
q7.explanation: In a minor accident with no injuries, exchange information with the other driver including names, addresses, and insurance details.
q7.o1: Exchange information with the other driver

q8.text: What should you do if you hit a parked car?
q8.explanation: If you hit a parked car, leave a note with your contact information and report the incident to your insurance company.
q8.o1: Leave a note with your contact information
q8.o2: Wait for the owner to return

q9.text: What should you do if you are involved in an accident with a cyclist or pedestrian?
q9.explanation: If you are involved in an accident with a cyclist or pedestrian, stop immediately and call emergency services (112).
q9.o2: Stop immediately and call emergency services
q9.o3: Wait for someone else to help

q10.text: What should you do if your vehicle catches fire?
q10.explanation: If your vehicle catches fire, stop immediately and evacuate everyone from the vehicle. Call emergency services and move to a safe distance.
q10.o1: Try to put out the fire yourself

q11.text: What should you do if you witness a hit-and-run accident?
q11.explanation: If you witness a hit-and-run accident, call the police and provide as many details as possible about the fleeing vehicle.
q11.o2: Call the police and provide details

q12.text: What should you do if you are involved in an accident with an uninsured driver?
q12.explanation: If you are involved in an accident with an uninsured driver, call the police and your insurance company immediately.
q12.o2: Call the police and your insurance company

q1.text: What is a "milieuzone" (environmental zone) in the Netherlands?
q1.explanation: A "milieuzone" (environmental zone) is a city center area where certain vehicles are restricted from entering to improve air quality and reduce pollution.
q1.o2: A city center with restricted vehicle access
q1.o3: A parking area for electric vehicles

q2.text: Which vehicles are typically restricted in environmental zones?
q2.explanation: Environmental zones typically restrict diesel vehicles and older cars that do not meet current emission standards to improve air quality.

q3.text: What sign indicates the entrance to an environmental zone?
q3.explanation: The entrance to an environmental zone is marked with a red circle containing "MILIEUZONE" to indicate restricted access.

q4.text: What sign indicates the exit from an environmental zone?
q4.explanation: The exit from an environmental zone is marked with a red circle containing "MILIEUZONE" with a diagonal line through it.
q4.o1: A red circle with "MILIEUZONE" and a diagonal line
q4.o2: A blue circle with "MILIEUZONE" and a diagonal line
q4.o3: A green circle with "MILIEUZONE" and a diagonal line
q4.o4: A yellow triangle with "MILIEUZONE" and a diagonal line

q5.text: What is the penalty for entering an environmental zone with a restricted vehicle?
q5.explanation: Entering an environmental zone with a restricted vehicle typically results in a fine of €95.

q6.text: Which vehicles are usually exempt from environmental zone restrictions?
q6.explanation: Emergency vehicles and electric vehicles are usually exempt from environmental zone restrictions as they have low or zero emissions.

q1.text: At an intersection with no traffic signs or signals, who has the right of way?
q1.explanation: At an intersection with no traffic signs or signals, traffic from the right has the right of way. This is known as the "right before left" rule.

q2.text: At a T-junction, who has the right of way?
q2.explanation: At a T-junction, traffic on the through road has the right of way. Traffic turning onto the through road must yield.
q2.o2: Traffic turning onto the through road

q3.text: At a roundabout, who has the right of way?
q3.explanation: At a roundabout, traffic already on the roundabout has the right of way. Traffic entering the roundabout must yield.

q4.text: When merging onto a motorway, who has the right of way?
q4.explanation: When merging onto a motorway, traffic already on the motorway has the right of way. Merging traffic must adjust their speed and find a gap.
q4.o3: The vehicle with the higher speed
q4.o4: The vehicle in the left lane

q5.text: When changing lanes, who has the right of way?
q5.explanation: When changing lanes, the vehicle already in the lane has the right of way. The vehicle changing lanes must yield and find a safe gap.
q5.o2: The vehicle already in the lane
q5.o3: The vehicle with the higher speed
q5.o4: The vehicle in the left lane

q6.text: At an intersection with a "Stop" sign, who has the right of way?
q6.explanation: At an intersection with a "Stop" sign, the vehicle at the stop sign must yield to all other traffic before proceeding.
q6.o1: The vehicle at the stop sign

q7.text: At an intersection with a "Give Way" sign, who has the right of way?
q7.explanation: At an intersection with a "Give Way" sign, the vehicle at the give way sign must yield to all other traffic before proceeding.
q7.o1: The vehicle at the give way sign

q8.text: When a traffic light turns green, who has the right of way?
q8.explanation: When a traffic light turns green, all traffic with a green light has the right of way, but must still yield to pedestrians and emergency vehicles.
q8.o1: All traffic with a green light

q9.text: When a traffic light turns yellow, what should you do?
q9.explanation: When a traffic light turns yellow, you should stop if it is safe to do so. Only proceed if you cannot stop safely.
q9.o2: Stop if it is safe to do so

q10.text: When a traffic light turns red, what should you do?
q10.explanation: When a traffic light turns red, you must stop completely and wait for the light to turn green before proceeding.

q11.text: When a traffic light is flashing yellow, what should you do?
q11.explanation: When a traffic light is flashing yellow, you should proceed with caution and be prepared to stop if necessary.

q12.text: When a traffic light is not working, what should you do?
q12.explanation: When a traffic light is not working, you should treat it as a stop sign and yield to other traffic before proceeding.
q12.o1: Treat it as a stop sign

q1.text: What are the signs of driver fatigue?
q1.explanation: Signs of driver fatigue include yawning, heavy eyelids, difficulty concentrating, drifting in lane, missing exits, and feeling restless or irritable.
q1.o3: Yawning, heavy eyelids, difficulty concentrating, and drifting in lane

q2.text: How often should you take breaks on long journeys?
q2.explanation: You should take a break every 2 hours on long journeys, even if you don\

q3.text: How long should each break be on a long journey?
q3.explanation: Each break should be 15-20 minutes long. This gives you enough time to rest, stretch, and refresh yourself before continuing your journey.

q4.text: What should you do if you feel tired while driving?
q4.explanation: If you feel tired while driving, you should pull over in a safe place and rest. Never try to continue driving when fatigued.
q4.o1: Continue driving and try to stay awake
q4.o2: Open the window and turn up the radio
q4.o3: Pull over in a safe place and rest

q5.text: How much sleep should you get before a long journey?
q5.explanation: You should get 7-8 hours of sleep before a long journey to ensure you are well-rested and alert while driving.

q6.text: What is microsleep?
q6.explanation: Microsleep is a brief period of unconsciousness lasting 1-30 seconds. It can occur without warning and is extremely dangerous while driving.
q6.o2: A brief period of unconsciousness lasting 1-30 seconds

q7.text: What should you do if you experience microsleep while driving?
q7.explanation: If you experience microsleep while driving, you should pull over immediately in a safe place and rest. This is a serious warning sign of fatigue.
q7.o3: Take a short nap in the car

q8.text: What is the best time to plan long journeys?
q8.explanation: The best time to plan long journeys is early morning when you are fresh and alert. Avoid driving during your normal sleep hours.
q8.o1: Early morning when you are fresh

q9.text: What should you avoid before a long journey?
q9.explanation: Before a long journey, you should avoid heavy meals, alcohol, and medications that cause drowsiness, as they can all contribute to fatigue.

q10.text: What should you do during breaks on long journeys?
q10.explanation: During breaks on long journeys, you should get out of the car, stretch, walk around, and get some fresh air to help stay alert.
q10.o1: Stay in the car and rest
q10.o2: Get out, stretch, and walk around

q11.text: What is the recommended maximum driving time per day?
q11.explanation: The recommended maximum driving time per day is 8 hours, including breaks. This helps prevent fatigue and maintains safety.

q12.text: What should you do if you are driving and start to feel drowsy?
q12.explanation: If you start to feel drowsy while driving, you should pull over in a safe place and take a short nap. Coffee and other stimulants are not reliable solutions.
q12.o2: Pull over and take a short nap

q1.text: Your speed is 50 km/h. A child on a scooter suddenly emerges from behind the parked car on the right. What do you do?
q1.explanation: Immediate braking is necessary as a child has suddenly appeared in your path, creating a high-risk situation.

q2.text: Your speed is 30 km/h. A pedestrian looking at their phone steps off the pavement from between parked cars. What do you do?
q2.explanation: Braking is required as a pedestrian has unexpectedly entered the roadway without looking, posing an immediate collision risk.

q3.text: Your speed is 80 km/h on a country road. A deer suddenly jumps out from bushes on the side, about 50 meters ahead. No oncoming traffic is visible. What do you do?
q3.explanation: A deer at 50 meters at 80 km/h is an immediate hazard requiring emergency braking to avoid a collision.

q4.text: Your speed is 50 km/h approaching a T-junction on your right. A car is at the give-way line, partially obscured by a hedge. Its front wheels start to turn slightly as if to pull out. What do you do?
q4.explanation: Releasing the accelerator allows you to assess if the car will fully emerge and prepares you to brake if necessary, without overreacting if it waits.

q5.text: Your speed is 100 km/h in the middle lane of a three-lane motorway. The car ahead of you, without indicating, suddenly swerves into your lane to avoid a much slower vehicle in its original lane. What do you do?
q5.explanation: A vehicle suddenly swerving into your lane at high speed requires immediate braking to avoid a collision and maintain a safe following distance.

q6.text: Your speed is 30 km/h in a residential area. Children are playing football on a grass verge. A ball rolls onto the road just ahead, and a child starts to run towards it. What do you do?
q6.explanation: A child running after a ball into the road is a high-risk situation requiring immediate braking to prevent hitting the child.

q7.text: Your speed is 60 km/h approaching a slight bend to the left on a two-lane road. An oncoming vehicle appears to be drifting slightly towards the centerline as it negotiates the bend. What do you do?
q7.explanation: Releasing the accelerator provides more space and time to react if the oncoming vehicle crosses the centerline. It is a cautious approach to a potential hazard.

q8.text: Your speed is 70 km/h on a main road approaching traffic lights about 150 meters ahead. They are currently green but suddenly change to amber. What do you do?
q8.explanation: Releasing the accelerator is the initial action to assess if a safe stop can be made before the stop line. If too close to stop safely, you might proceed through amber, but the primary action is to prepare to stop.

q9.text: Your speed is 10 km/h in very slow-moving/queuing traffic. A motorcyclist is filtering between your lane and the lane to your right, approaching from behind. The gap is tight. What do you do?
q9.explanation: In very slow or stationary traffic, maintain your position and speed (or lack thereof). Sudden braking or swerving can be dangerous for the filtering motorcyclist. Allow them to pass.

q10.text: Your speed is 50 km/h driving towards a junction where you intend to turn right. The sun is very low, causing significant glare and making it very difficult to see if any vehicles are emerging from the side road. What do you do?
q10.explanation: Severe glare significantly reduces visibility. Release the accelerator to slow down considerably and be prepared to brake or stop if needed as you cannot clearly see potential hazards at the junction.

q1.text: You are approaching a T-junction and want to turn right onto a busy main road. Your view to the left is blocked by a parked van, and traffic is moving quickly.\n\nWhat is the safest way to proceed?
q1.explanation: Always wait for a clear view and a safe gap before joining a busy road, especially when your view is blocked. Never assume others will slow down for you.
q1.o1: Rely on your ability to accelerate quickly and join the traffic as soon as possible.
q1.o2: Wait until you have a clear view and there is a safe gap in both directions, even if it takes longer.
q1.o3: Assume drivers from the right will slow down for you as you enter.

q2.text: You have just overtaken a lorry on a three-lane motorway and are now in the middle lane. The right lane is clear, and there is another slower vehicle further ahead in the left lane.\n\nWhat should you do according to proper motorway driving discipline?
q2.explanation: On motorways, you must return to the left-most lane as soon as it is safe. Only use other lanes for overtaking.
q2.o1: Stay in the middle lane to overtake the next vehicle ahead.
q2.o2: Move to the right lane to give yourself more space from other traffic.
q2.o3: Return to the left lane as soon as it is safe, and only move out again when overtaking.

q3.text: You are driving along a residential street with parked cars on your left. A cyclist is riding ahead of you, close to the parked cars.\n\nWhat is the main hazard you should anticipate?
q3.explanation: Always anticipate that a cyclist may swerve if a car door opens. Give cyclists extra space when passing parked cars.
q3.o1: The cyclist suddenly speeding up and creating a gap.
q3.o2: A car door opening unexpectedly, causing the cyclist to swerve into your path.
q3.o3: The cyclist signaling to turn left across your path without much warning.

q4.text: You encounter dense fog on a familiar road, and visibility is reduced to about 50 meters.\n\nWhat is the best action to take?
q4.explanation: In fog, reduce speed, use dipped headlights and fog lights if visibility is below 50m, and be able to stop within the distance you can see.
q4.o1: Turn on your full beam headlights to see further into the fog.
q4.o2: Maintain your normal speed but double your following distance.
q4.o3: Reduce your speed significantly, use dipped headlights (and fog lights if needed), and be ready to stop within the visible distance.

q5.text: You are approaching a zebra crossing. A pedestrian is standing at the edge, looking in your direction, but has not yet stepped onto the crossing.\n\nWhat should you do?
q5.explanation: Always anticipate that a pedestrian may step onto the crossing. Slow down and be ready to stop.
q5.o1: Continue at your current speed as they have not stepped onto the crossing.
q5.o2: Slow down and be fully prepared to stop, making eye contact if possible.
q5.o3: Sound your horn to let them know it is safe to cross after you pass.

q6.text: You are approaching an unmarked crossroads in a residential area. Another vehicle is approaching from your right, and you will arrive at the junction at the same time.\n\nWho has priority in this situation?

q6.o2: The vehicle from your right has priority.

q7.text: You are following a slow-moving tractor on a single carriageway road. There is a solid white line on your side of the center marking. The road ahead appears clear for a long distance.\n\nWhat should you do?
q7.explanation: A solid white line means you must not cross or straddle it to overtake, regardless of how clear the road ahead seems.

q7.o2: Do not overtake because the solid white line prohibits crossing it for overtaking.
q7.o3: Edge out slightly to see if the tractor driver waves you past, then overtake if they do.

q8.text: You are driving past a park where children are playing football close to the road. There is a waist-high fence separating the park from the pavement and road.\n\nWhat is the safest approach?
q8.explanation: Children playing near a road require extra caution, even with a fence. Be ready for sudden, unpredictable actions.
q8.o1: Maintain normal caution; the fence provides adequate safety separation.
q8.o2: Reduce speed and be extra alert; children or a ball could still come onto the road unexpectedly.
q8.o3: No special caution is needed unless a child is visibly climbing the fence.

q9.text: On a 100 km/h dual carriageway, you see a queue of stationary or very slow-moving traffic ahead in your lane due to congestion.\n\nWhat is the best way to warn following traffic and reduce risk?
q9.explanation: Early, smooth braking and using hazard lights to warn following traffic is safest when approaching a sudden queue.
q9.o1: Maintain your speed for as long as possible then brake hard to minimize time lost and fit into the queue.
q9.o2: Check mirrors, brake early and smoothly, and briefly activate your hazard warning lights to alert following traffic.
q9.o3: Immediately look for an opportunity to switch to the adjacent lane to bypass the queue, even if it means cutting in.

q10.text: You are due to drive early in the morning but have taken an over-the-counter cold and flu medication the night before. The packaging warns that the medication "may cause drowsiness." You feel slightly tired but otherwise okay.\n\nWhat should you do?
q10.explanation: Never drive if you may be impaired by medication. If in doubt, do not drive.
q10.o1: Drive as planned; the main effects of the medication should have worn off overnight.
q10.o2: Have a strong coffee before driving to counteract any residual drowsiness.
q10.o3: Do not drive. Find another way to travel or postpone your journey until you are sure you are not affected.

q1.text: What is the minimum speed limit on a motorway in the Netherlands?
q1.explanation: The minimum speed limit on a motorway in the Netherlands is 60 km/h. Vehicles that cannot maintain this speed are not allowed on motorways.

q2.text: Which vehicles are not allowed on motorways?
q2.explanation: Mopeds and tractors are not allowed on motorways as they cannot maintain the minimum speed limit and would create a safety hazard.

q3.text: What should you do if your vehicle breaks down on a motorway?
q3.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a motorway, you should get out of your vehicle and stand behind the safety barrier. Call for assistance using the emergency phones.
q3.o2: Get out and stand behind the barrier
q3.o3: Walk along the motorway to find help
q3.o4: Try to repair the vehicle yourself

q4.text: What is the purpose of the hard shoulder on a motorway?
q4.explanation: The hard shoulder is reserved for emergency stops and breakdowns only. It should not be used for normal driving, overtaking, or parking.

q5.text: What should you do when approaching a motorway exit?
q5.explanation: When approaching a motorway exit, you should move to the right lane early and reduce your speed gradually to safely exit the motorway.
q5.o1: Speed up to get through quickly
q5.o2: Move to the left lane early
q5.o3: Move to the right lane early
q5.o4: Honk your horn to signal your intention

q6.text: What should you do when entering a motorway?
q6.explanation: When entering a motorway, you should accelerate to match the speed of traffic on the motorway and merge safely into a gap.
q6.o1: Stop and wait for a large gap
q6.o3: Slow down to let other vehicles pass
q6.o4: Honk your horn to signal your intention

q7.text: What does a variable speed limit sign on a motorway mean?
q7.explanation: Variable speed limit signs on motorways display mandatory speed limits that you must follow. These are used to manage traffic flow and improve safety.
q7.o2: You must follow the displayed speed limit
q7.o3: The speed limit only applies to trucks
q7.o4: The speed limit only applies at night

q8.text: What should you do if you miss your motorway exit?
q8.explanation: If you miss your motorway exit, you should continue to the next exit and find an alternative route. Never reverse, stop, or turn around on a motorway.
q8.o4: Use the hard shoulder to turn around

q9.text: What is the purpose of lane markings on a motorway?
q9.explanation: Lane markings on motorways help organize traffic flow, prevent accidents, and ensure safe driving by clearly defining where vehicles should drive.
q9.o1: To separate different types of vehicles
q9.o2: To organize traffic flow and prevent accidents

q10.text: What should you do when overtaking on a motorway?
q10.explanation: When overtaking on a motorway, you should use the left lane (the lane to the left of the vehicle you are overtaking).

q11.text: What should you do when being overtaken on a motorway?
q11.explanation: When being overtaken on a motorway, you should maintain your speed and position. Do not speed up or change lanes unnecessarily.
q11.o1: Speed up to prevent being overtaken
q11.o4: Honk your horn to signal your position

q12.text: What should you do if you see an emergency vehicle on a motorway?
q12.explanation: If you see an emergency vehicle on a motorway, you should move to the right lane and slow down to allow it to pass safely.
q12.o2: Move to the right and slow down
q12.o3: Speed up to get out of the way

q1.text: What is the minimum distance you must park from a pedestrian crossing?
q1.explanation: You must park at least 5 meters from a pedestrian crossing to ensure pedestrians have a clear view of approaching traffic.

q2.text: What is the minimum distance you must park from a junction?
q2.explanation: You must park at least 5 meters from a junction to ensure other drivers have a clear view of approaching traffic.

q3.text: What is the minimum distance you must park from a bus stop?
q3.explanation: You must park at least 10 meters from a bus stop to allow buses to pull in and out safely.

q4.text: What is the minimum distance you must park from a fire hydrant?
q4.explanation: You must park at least 5 meters from a fire hydrant to ensure emergency services can access it when needed.

q5.text: What is the minimum distance you must park from a railway crossing?
q5.explanation: You must park at least 20 meters from a railway crossing to ensure trains have a clear view and can stop safely if needed.

q6.text: What does a solid yellow line along the edge of the road indicate?
q6.explanation: A solid yellow line along the edge of the road indicates that parking is not allowed at any time.

q7.text: What does a broken yellow line along the edge of the road indicate?
q7.explanation: A broken yellow line along the edge of the road indicates that stopping is not allowed, which means you cannot stop or park your vehicle there.

q8.text: What does a blue line along the edge of the road indicate?
q8.explanation: A blue line indicates parking reserved for disabled persons. You must have a valid disabled parking permit to park here.

q9.text: What does a white "P" sign with a car symbol indicate?
q9.explanation: A white "P" sign with a car symbol indicates that parking is permitted. Look for additional information on any conditions or restrictions.

q10.text: What does a "No Parking" sign with a red circle and crossed-out "P" indicate?
q10.explanation: A "No Parking" sign with a red circle and crossed-out "P" indicates that parking is not allowed at any time.

q11.text: What does a "No Stopping" sign with a red circle and crossed-out "S" indicate?
q11.explanation: A "No Stopping" sign with a red circle and crossed-out "S" indicates that stopping is not allowed, which means you cannot stop or park your vehicle there.

q12.text: What does a "Resident Parking" sign indicate?
q12.explanation: A "Resident Parking" sign indicates that parking is reserved for residents of the area. You must have a valid resident parking permit to park here.

q1.text: You are driving and see a pedestrian waiting at a zebra crossing. What should you do?
q1.explanation: At zebra crossings, you must stop and give way to pedestrians who are waiting to cross or already crossing.

q2.text: You are driving and see a pedestrian crossing at a traffic light. The light is green for you. What should you do?

q4.o2: Continue driving, the light is red for pedestrians

q3.text: At an unmarked crossroads, which vehicle has priority?
q3.explanation: At an unmarked crossroads, the "priority to the right" rule applies. Vehicles approaching from the right have priority.

q4.text: What does a "Give Way" sign (inverted triangle) mean?
q4.explanation: A "Give Way" sign means you must slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary to give way to traffic on the priority road.

q5.explanation: At a T-junction, vehicles on the through road (the top of the T) typically have priority over vehicles turning into the junction.

q5.o3: The vehicle approaching from the left

q6.text: What is the priority rule for emergency vehicles with flashing lights and sirens?
q6.explanation: Emergency vehicles with flashing lights and sirens have priority over all other traffic. You must give way and allow them to pass safely.
q6.o1: They must follow normal traffic rules
q6.o2: They have priority over all other traffic and you must give way
q6.o3: They only have priority at traffic lights

q7.text: At a roundabout, who has priority?
q7.explanation: At a roundabout, traffic already on the roundabout has priority over traffic waiting to enter. You must give way to traffic on your right.

q8.text: What does a "Stop" sign (octagonal red sign) require you to do?
q8.explanation: A "Stop" sign requires you to stop completely at the stop line and give way to all traffic on the priority road before proceeding.
q8.o1: Slow down and proceed if the way is clear
q8.o2: Stop completely and give way to all traffic
q8.o3: Stop only if other vehicles are present

q1.o2: Enter immediately if no cars are visible

q1.explanation: The maximum speed limit for cars on Dutch motorways is 100 km/h during good weather conditions. This was reduced from 130 km/h to 100 km/h in 2020 and remains at 100 km/h.

q2.text: What is the speed limit for cars in built-up areas (within city limits) in the Netherlands?
q2.explanation: The standard speed limit in built-up areas in the Netherlands is 50 km/h, unless otherwise indicated by traffic signs.

q3.text: What is the speed limit for cars on rural roads outside built-up areas?
q3.explanation: On rural roads outside built-up areas, the speed limit for cars is 80 km/h, unless a different limit is indicated by traffic signs.

q4.text: What is the speed limit for cars on a motorway during bad weather conditions (rain, snow, fog)?
q4.explanation: During bad weather conditions, the speed limit on motorways is reduced to 100 km/h for safety reasons.

q5.text: What is the speed limit for cars in a 30 km/h zone?
q5.explanation: In a 30 km/h zone, the maximum speed limit is 30 km/h. These zones are typically found in residential areas, near schools, or in areas with high pedestrian activity.

q6.text: What is the speed limit for cars on a motorway at night (between 19:00 and 06:00)?
q6.explanation: At night (between 19:00 and 06:00), the speed limit on motorways is 100 km/h to reduce noise pollution and improve safety.

q7.text: What is the speed limit for cars on a dual carriageway (autoweg) outside built-up areas?
q7.explanation: On dual carriageways (autoweg) outside built-up areas, the speed limit for cars is 100 km/h.

q8.text: What is the speed limit for cars when towing a trailer on a motorway?
q8.explanation: When towing a trailer on a motorway, the speed limit is 90 km/h for safety reasons.

q9.text: What is the speed limit for cars in a roadworks zone on a motorway?
q9.explanation: In roadworks zones on motorways, the speed limit is typically reduced to 70 km/h to ensure the safety of workers and drivers.

q10.text: What is the speed limit for cars in a residential area with speed bumps?
q10.explanation: In residential areas with speed bumps, the speed limit is typically 30 km/h to ensure pedestrian safety.

q11.text: What is the speed limit for cars on a motorway when there is a variable speed limit sign showing 80 km/h?
q11.explanation: When a variable speed limit sign shows 80 km/h, you must follow that limit, which overrides the normal motorway speed limit.

q12.text: What is the speed limit for cars in a special zone marked with a "Zone 30" sign?
q12.explanation: A "Zone 30" sign indicates that the speed limit is 30 km/h throughout the entire zone, not just at the entrance.

q1.text: What does ABS (Anti-lock Braking System) do?
q1.explanation: ABS (Anti-lock Braking System) prevents the wheels from locking during hard braking, allowing the driver to maintain steering control and reduce stopping distance.
q1.o1: Prevents the wheels from locking during braking

q2.text: What does ESP (Electronic Stability Program) do?
q2.explanation: ESP (Electronic Stability Program) helps maintain vehicle stability during cornering by automatically applying brakes to individual wheels when it detects loss of control.
q2.o2: Helps maintain vehicle stability during cornering

q3.text: What is a rear-view camera used for?
q3.explanation: A rear-view camera helps with reversing and parking by providing a clear view of the area behind the vehicle, reducing blind spots.
q3.o2: To help with reversing and parking

q4.text: What does Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC) do?
q4.explanation: Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC) maintains a set speed while automatically adjusting to maintain a safe distance from the vehicle ahead.
q4.o2: Maintains a safe distance from the vehicle ahead

q5.text: What does Lane Departure Warning (LDW) do?
q5.explanation: Lane Departure Warning (LDW) warns the driver when the vehicle drifts out of the lane without using the turn signal.
q5.o1: Automatically steers the vehicle back into the lane
q5.o2: Warns the driver when the vehicle drifts out of the lane

q6.text: What does Blind Spot Monitoring (BSM) do?
q6.explanation: Blind Spot Monitoring (BSM) warns the driver of vehicles in the blind spot when changing lanes.
q6.o2: Warns of vehicles in the blind spot

q7.text: What does Autonomous Emergency Braking (AEB) do?
q7.explanation: Autonomous Emergency Braking (AEB) automatically applies the brakes to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision when it detects an imminent crash.
q7.o1: Automatically applies brakes to prevent collisions

q8.text: What does Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS) do?
q8.explanation: Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS) warns the driver when tire pressure is too low, which can affect safety and fuel efficiency.

q1.o1: Accelerate to pass through before it turns red.
q1.o2: Stop before the stop line, unless you are so close that to stop safely would cause an accident.
q1.o3: Continue at the same speed as it means the lights are about to turn green.

q2.text: What does a green filter arrow (e.g., for turning left) at traffic lights indicate when the main light is red?
q2.explanation: A green filter arrow allows you to proceed in the direction of the arrow, even if the main light is red, provided you give way to any pedestrians or other road users who have priority.
q2.o1: You may turn left if the way is clear, but give way to pedestrians crossing.
q2.o2: You must wait for the main green light before turning left.
q2.o3: You have priority over all other traffic and pedestrians when turning left.

q3.text: If traffic lights are out of order (not working at all), how should you treat the junction?
q3.explanation: When traffic lights are out of order, revert to standard priority rules as if the junction is unmarked, or follow any existing give way/stop signs. Always proceed with caution.
q3.o1: Treat it as if you have priority over all traffic.
q3.o2: Proceed with extreme caution and treat the junction as an unmarked crossroads or give way, depending on road markings or signs.
q3.o3: Wait for a police officer to direct traffic before proceeding.

q4.text: What does a flashing amber beacon mounted above a pedestrian crossing (Pelican or Puffin crossing) signify when pedestrians are crossing?
q4.explanation: A flashing amber beacon at a pedestrian crossing means you must give way to pedestrians on the crossing, but you may proceed if the crossing is clear.
q4.o1: You must stop and wait until the beacon stops flashing.
q4.o2: You may proceed if the way is clear, giving way to pedestrians still on the crossing.
q4.o3: The crossing is out of order; proceed normally.

q5.text: A police officer is directing traffic at a junction and signals you to stop, but the traffic light for you is green. What must you do?
q5.explanation: Signals given by a police officer directing traffic override all other traffic signals and signs. You must obey the officer.
q5.o1: Obey the green traffic light and proceed.
q5.o2: Point to the green light to inform the officer and then proceed.

q6.text: At a level crossing, twin flashing red lights have started to flash. What is your immediate action?
q6.explanation: Twin flashing red lights at a level crossing mean a train is approaching. You must stop before the stop line or barrier and wait.
q6.o1: Stop immediately, even if you are already on the crossing.
q6.o2: Stop before the barrier or stop line and wait until the lights stop flashing and any barrier is fully raised.
q6.o3: Cross quickly if you cannot see or hear a train approaching.

q7.text: Some traffic lights have a white light signal for trams or buses. What does a steady white horizontal bar mean for these vehicles?
q7.explanation: For trams or buses, a steady white horizontal bar at a traffic light signal typically means "Stop".

q8.text: You see a signal light showing a red bicycle symbol. What does this mean for cyclists?
q8.explanation: A red bicycle symbol at traffic lights means cyclists must stop and wait for the green signal specific to them or a general green light.
q8.o2: Cyclists must stop and wait for a green bicycle signal.
q8.o3: Cyclists can proceed if no other traffic is present.

q9.text: What is an "intelligent" or "adaptive" traffic light system designed to do?
q9.explanation: Adaptive traffic light systems use sensors to detect traffic volume and adjust signal timings to optimize flow and reduce delays.
q9.o1: Change lights at fixed intervals regardless of traffic.
q9.o2: Prioritize buses and emergency vehicles by giving them immediate green lights.
q9.o3: Adjust light timings based on real-time traffic flow detected by sensors.

q10.text: If a traffic light shows red and amber together, what should you prepare to do?
q10.explanation: Red and amber lights showing together indicate that the lights are about to change to green. You should prepare to proceed when it turns green.
q10.o1: Stop, as the lights are about to turn red.
q10.o2: Proceed with caution, as the lights are faulty.
q10.o3: Prepare to go; the lights will shortly change to green.

q1.text: You are driving and see a tram approaching from behind. What should you do?
q1.explanation: Trams have priority over other vehicles. You must give way to trams and allow them to pass safely.
q1.o3: Speed up to avoid the tram

q2.text: You are driving and see a tram stopped at a tram stop. What should you do?
q2.explanation: When a tram is stopped at a tram stop, you must stop and wait for passengers to safely board or alight before proceeding.
q2.o1: Stop and wait for passengers to board/alight

q3.text: You are driving and see a tram crossing your path. What should you do?
q3.explanation: Trams have priority at intersections and crossings. You must give way to trams and wait for them to pass.
q3.o2: Continue driving, trams must give way
q3.o3: Speed up to cross before the tram

q4.text: You are driving on a road with tram tracks. What should you do?
q4.explanation: When driving on roads with tram tracks, drive carefully and be constantly aware of trams that may be approaching.
q4.o1: Drive carefully and be aware of trams
q4.o2: Drive normally, trams will avoid you
q4.o3: Avoid driving on roads with tram tracks

q5.text: You are driving and see a tram with flashing lights. What should you do?
q5.explanation: Trams with flashing lights have priority and may be making an emergency stop. Give way to them immediately.
q5.o1: Give way to the tram immediately
q5.o3: Honk to warn the tram driver

q6.text: You are driving and see a tram approaching from the opposite direction. What should you do?
q6.explanation: When a tram is approaching from the opposite direction, give it extra space and be prepared to stop if necessary.
q6.o1: Drive normally, trams have their own lane
q6.o2: Give extra space to the tram
q6.o3: Stop completely and let the tram pass

q7.text: You are driving and see a tram making a turn. What should you do?
q7.explanation: Trams have priority when making turns. You must give way to trams and wait for them to complete their turn.
q7.o2: Continue driving, trams must give way
q7.o3: Speed up to avoid the tram

q8.text: You are driving and see a tram at a tram stop with passengers boarding. What should you do?
q8.explanation: When a tram is at a stop with passengers boarding, you must stop and wait for the tram to depart before proceeding.
q8.o1: Stop and wait for the tram to depart

q9.text: You are driving and see a tram with its doors open. What should you do?
q9.explanation: When a tram has its doors open, it means passengers are boarding or alighting. You must stop and wait for the doors to close.
q9.o1: Stop and wait for the doors to close
q9.o3: Honk to warn the tram driver

q10.text: You are driving and see a tram with a red light. What should you do?
q10.explanation: Trams with red lights have priority and may be making an emergency stop. You must give way to them immediately.
q10.o3: Honk to warn the tram driver

q1.text: What is the speed limit for motorcycles on motorways in the Netherlands?
q1.explanation: Motorcycles have the same speed limit as cars on motorways in the Netherlands, which is 130 km/h during good weather conditions.

q2.text: What is the speed limit for trucks on motorways in the Netherlands?
q2.explanation: Trucks have a speed limit of 80 km/h on motorways in the Netherlands, regardless of the weather conditions.

q3.text: What is the speed limit for buses on motorways in the Netherlands?
q3.explanation: Buses have a speed limit of 80 km/h on motorways in the Netherlands, the same as trucks.

q4.text: What is the speed limit for mopeds on roads in the Netherlands?
q4.explanation: Mopeds have a speed limit of 45 km/h on roads in the Netherlands, unless otherwise indicated by traffic signs.

q5.text: What is the speed limit for tractors on roads in the Netherlands?
q5.explanation: Tractors have a speed limit of 25 km/h on roads in the Netherlands, unless they have special permission for higher speeds.

q6.text: Which lane should motorcycles use on a three-lane motorway?
q6.explanation: Motorcycles can use any lane on a motorway, just like cars. They should follow the same lane discipline rules.

q7.text: Which lane should trucks use on a three-lane motorway?
q7.explanation: Trucks should use the middle and right lanes on a three-lane motorway. They are not allowed to use the left lane for overtaking.

q8.text: What is the speed limit for cars towing trailers on motorways?
q8.explanation: Cars towing trailers have a speed limit of 90 km/h on motorways in the Netherlands.

q1.text: What documents must you carry when driving in the Netherlands?
q1.explanation: You must carry your driving license, vehicle registration document (kentekenbewijs), insurance certificate, and MOT certificate (APK) when driving.
q1.o2: Driving license and vehicle registration document
q1.o3: Driving license, vehicle registration, insurance certificate, and MOT certificate

q2.text: What is the APK (Algemene Periodieke Keuring)?
q2.explanation: APK (Algemene Periodieke Keuring) is the annual vehicle safety and emissions test that all vehicles must pass to be roadworthy.
q2.o2: Annual vehicle safety and emissions test

q3.text: How often must a new car have an APK test?
q3.explanation: A new car must have its first APK test after 3 years, then every year thereafter.

q4.text: What happens if you drive without valid insurance?
q4.explanation: Driving without valid insurance results in a heavy fine and possible vehicle confiscation. It is a serious offense.
q4.o3: Heavy fine and possible vehicle confiscation

q5.text: What is the minimum insurance coverage required in the Netherlands?
q5.explanation: The minimum insurance coverage required in the Netherlands is third-party liability insurance (WA-verzekering).

q6.text: What should you do if you lose your driving license?
q6.explanation: If you lose your driving license, you should report it to the police and apply for a replacement at your local municipality.
q6.o2: Report it to the police and apply for a replacement

q7.text: What is the penalty for driving without a valid driving license?
q7.explanation: Driving without a valid driving license is a serious offense that can result in a heavy fine and possible imprisonment.

q8.text: What should you do if your vehicle registration document is stolen?
q8.explanation: If your vehicle registration document is stolen, you should report it to the police and apply for a replacement at the RDW.
q8.o2: Report it to the police and apply for a replacement

q9.text: What is the RDW (Rijksdienst voor het Wegverkeer)?
q9.explanation: The RDW (Rijksdienst voor het Wegverkeer) is the Dutch vehicle registration and licensing authority responsible for vehicle documentation.
q9.o2: Dutch vehicle registration and licensing authority

q10.text: What should you do if you buy a used car?
q10.explanation: When you buy a used car, you must transfer ownership within 14 days at the RDW or a post office.

q11.text: What happens if you fail to transfer vehicle ownership on time?
q11.explanation: Failing to transfer vehicle ownership within 14 days results in a fine of €340.

q12.text: What should you do if you move to a different address?
q12.explanation: When you move to a different address, you must update both your driving license and vehicle registration addresses at your local municipality.
q12.o3: Update both driving license and vehicle registration addresses

q1.text: You are driving in heavy rain. What should you do?
q1.explanation: In heavy rain, reduce your speed and increase your following distance to account for reduced visibility and longer stopping distances.
q1.o1: Reduce speed and increase following distance
q1.o3: Speed up to get through the rain quickly

q2.text: You are driving in fog. What should you do?
q2.explanation: In fog, use low beam headlights (high beams reflect off fog and reduce visibility) and reduce your speed significantly.
q2.o1: Use low beam headlights and reduce speed
q2.o2: Use high beam headlights for better visibility

q3.text: You are driving in snow. What should you do?
q3.explanation: In snow, reduce your speed and use gentle braking to avoid skidding. Sudden movements can cause loss of control.
q3.o1: Reduce speed and use gentle braking
q3.o3: Speed up to get through the snow quickly

q4.text: You are driving in strong winds. What should you do?
q4.explanation: In strong winds, reduce your speed and hold the steering wheel firmly to maintain control of your vehicle.
q4.o1: Reduce speed and hold the steering wheel firmly
q4.o3: Speed up to get through the wind quickly
